body_html:
By default cpu:0 refers to all CPU cores on the system. You can create virtual CPU devices like "cpu:1", but there's no physical pinning of cores, so ops pinned to "cpu:1" will run on same cores as ops pinned to "cpu:0". To see what cores are actually being used to run ops you need to use something like ktrace utility.

Furthermore, I don't see anything in your script that will place ops onto cpu:1 virtual device, so that's why you see cpu:0 messages from placement algorithm

It's common to see less than full utilization because parallelization is hard (ie, some core are idle because they are waiting for input).
body_text:
By default cpu:0 refers to all CPU cores on the system. You can create virtual CPU devices like "cpu:1", but there's no physical pinning of cores, so ops pinned to "cpu:1" will run on same cores as ops pinned to "cpu:0". To see what cores are actually being used to run ops you need to use something like ktrace utility.
Furthermore, I don't see anything in your script that will place ops onto cpu:1 virtual device, so that's why you see cpu:0 messages from placement algorithm
It's common to see less than full utilization because parallelization is hard (ie, some core are idle because they are waiting for input).
body:
By default `cpu:0` refers to all CPU cores on the system. You can create virtual CPU devices like "cpu:1", but there's no physical pinning of cores, so ops pinned to "cpu:1" will run on same cores as ops pinned to "cpu:0". To see what cores are actually being used to run ops you need to use something like `ktrace` utility.

Furthermore, I don't see anything in your script that will place ops onto `cpu:1` virtual device, so that's why you see `cpu:0` messages from placement algorithm

It's common to see less than full utilization because parallelization is hard (ie, some core are idle because they are waiting for input).
